newsitem.title: USA: NASD muni overseer eyes pay-to-play waivers.
newsitem.headline: NASD muni overseer eyes pay-to-play waivers.

text.p: National Association of Securities Dealers' new muni compliance chief said Friday that bond firms need clearer guidance from his group on when they may qualify for waivers under MSRB's pay-to-play rule.
"I think there ought to be some bright lines," Malcolm Northam, director of fixed income securities regulation at NASD, said at NASD's Spring Securities Conference here.
He said he may be willing to grant waivers for one-time transgressions involving modest dollar amounts at firms with clear procedures in place for monitoring contributions.

Currently, NASD rarely grants waivers under the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board's pay-to-play rule G-37, which bars dealers that make contributions to issuer clients from doing business for two years with those governments.

But Northam, who joined NASD on May 5, said firms that uncover and report violations and have diligent recordkeeping procedures in place should be treated "a little bit differently" than firms with no procedures and whose violations were uncovered by investigators.
Northam said he did a quick review of NASD records of MSRB rule violations in the last half of 1996 and "the results are not pretty."
He said a whopping 32 percent were violations of MSRB's failure to supervise rule G-27 and 22 percent were problems with recordkeeping rule G-8.

"That's serious," Northam said of the G-27 violations. "This isn't one of those pesky little recordkeeping rules. Rule G-27 says you will maintain written procedures, have a compliance officer, and review on a regular basis muni transactions (for) irregularities."
Northam, who works for the the regulatory arm of NASD called NASD Regulation, said the recordkeeping violations probably were connected with political contributions reporting.

In other comments, Northam said NASDR inspectors will focus in months ahead on compliance with MSRB's transaction reporting rule G-14 and its rule G-36, which requires dealers to send copies of OSs to MSRB within certain timeframes.
"(We get) continual verbal complaints that it's impossible to get the official statements from the issuer, therefore, it's impossible to file it in a timely fashion," Northam said.
But Northam said the onus is on busy dealers to take the time to do the "follow-up" required to get the documents.

"The dealmakers do the deals and then (go) on to the next deal," he said. "I certainly understand the business side of the process. But, no one is following up -- either the middle or back office, or the underwriting syndicate manager -- to make sure it's done."

Northam said NASD also is getting "continual anecdotal complaints" that firms are not sending officials statements to investors at or before the date of final settlement, as required by MSRB rule G-32.
He said NASD also will be looking at that issue and other complaints about bond syndicate practices.

NASD conducts routine compliance exams of muni shops at least once every two years. "You shouldn't be surprised if we have a look at rules G-36, G-37 and G-38. So go back and fix the issues that are there before we have to find them," he said.
He said while setting up compliance procedures at firms tends to be "messy," it is important. "This is not inconsequential stuff," he said.
Northam said, in general, NASD district o ffices are not going to be very "patient" with firms out of sync with rules G-37 and G-36.
"These rules have been around for awhile. I don't think we ought to expect disrict offices to listen to you whine and complain," he said, stressing that those were his personal views

He said if firms try to "bury" problems with political contributions, for instance, NASD has the option of reviewing political filing records in the particular state. "We can simply go down through the campaign records and find out who gave," he said.
Northam said compliance officers at firms themselves should be "proactive."

Asked whether he means that dealers should research local campaign disclosure filings, Northam said, "I'm not suggesting they do anything of the sort." But he signaled that they could consider reviewing local records in some cases.
